questions.text: A 36-year-old man comes to the emergency department 4 hours after a bike accident for severe pain and swelling in his right leg. He has not had a headache, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, or blood in his urine. He has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease and allergic rhinitis. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 17 years and drinks an average of one alcoholic beverage daily. His medications include levocetirizine and pantoprazole. He is in moderate distress. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple bruises over both lower extremities and the face. There is swelling surrounding a 2 cm laceration 13 cm below the right knee. The lower two-thirds of the tibia is tender to palpation and the skin is pale and cool to the touch. The anterior tibial, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis pulses are weak. Capillary refill time of the right big toe is 4 seconds. Passive dorsiflexion of his right foot causes severe pain in his calf. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. An x-ray of the right leg shows a dislocated fracture of the tibial center with posterior displacement of the distal tibial part. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

One of the many indications of LMWH is the treatment of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). DVT can manifest with swelling of the lower limb and pain in the calf muscle on dorsiflexion of the foot. However, in patients with DVT, the extremities are usually warm and have a reddish-purple hue, normal pulses, and/or distended superficial veins.

B) INCORRECT:

Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) with an intramedullary nail are usually the treatment of choice for many types of open fractures of the tibial shaft, which this patient has. However, the presence of compartment syndrome warrants a more urgent procedure to save the limb before any definitive therapy is implemented.

C) INCORRECT:

An above knee cast may be used to nonsurgically treat a noncomminuted, minimally displaced tibial shaft fracture. However, this patient's fracture is open and has significant displacement, which requires surgical treatment. Regardless, a cast is contraindicated in this patient with compartment syndrome as it would drastically increase compartment pressure and further increase the risk of developing limb ischemia.

D) CORRECT:

Fasciotomy is the treatment of choice for compartment syndrome. It should be conducted within six hours of the onset of clinical symptoms (to prevent necrosis, irreversible nerve damage, and possible amputation) and followed up with open wound management. The diagnosis is primarily clinical; however, needle manometry to calculate the delta pressure (diastolic blood pressure - intracompartmental pressure) is often performed to confirm the diagnosis. A delta pressure < 30 mm Hg confirms acute compartment syndrome, which is an indication for fasciotomy. For patients who present extremely late (3–5 days after onset), amputation is the treatment of last resort.

E) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin is used to treat skin and soft tissue infections caused by anaerobic bacteria and certain gram-positive organisms such as MRSA. However, the history of trauma in this patient along with pale, cool skin instead of warm, erythematous skin, and the absence of fever suggest a noninfectious condition. If surgery is indicated, clindamycin is considered an alternative to cefazolin for surgical prophylaxis in patients with a beta-lactam allergy. However, the presence of compartment syndrome in this patient warrants a more urgent procedure to save the limb before any definitive therapy can be implemented.

F) INCORRECT:

Placing a filter within the inferior vena cava is indicated to treat and/or prevent pulmonary embolism in patients with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) when anticoagulant therapy is either contraindicated or ineffective. DVT can manifest with swelling of the lower limb, and pain in the calf muscle on dorsiflexion of the foot, as seen in this patient. But the extremities in a patient with DVT are usually warm with a reddish purple hue, normal pulses, and/or distended superficial veins.
questions.hint: Findings of a tibial fracture, pale, cool skin, weak peripheral pulses, increased capillary refill time, and pain in the calf muscle on passively dorsiflexing the foot are consistent with acute compartment syndrome and impending limb ischemia.

questions.text:
Two hours after undergoing a left femoral artery embolectomy, a 63-year-old woman has severe pain, numbness, and tingling in the left leg. The surgery was without complication and following the procedure, peripheral pulses were weakly palpable. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, peripheral artery disease, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. Prior to admission, her medications included insulin, enalapril, carvedilol, aspirin, and rosuvastatin. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 37.1°C (99.3°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 132/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a left groin surgical incision and swelling, stiffness, and exquisite tenderness to palpation of the left lower extremity. Femoral pulses are palpated bilaterally. Pedal pulses are weaker on the left side. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.1 g/dL


Leukocyte count
11,300/mm3



Platelet count
189,000/mm3



Serum



 Glucose
222 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


Results of urinalysis are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) of the lower extremity may manifest with asymmetric swelling and pain. However, an asymmetrical reduced pedal pulse and stiff extremity should raise concern for compartment syndrome. DVT may also be complicated by compartment syndrome but the rapid onset of this patient's symptoms and known ischemic injury (femoral arterial thrombus and thromboembolectomy) make another cause more likely. Ultrasound is a helpful diagnostic tool to distinguish DVT from compartment syndrome if physical examination findings are equivocal.

B) CORRECT:

Cases of extremity reperfusion injury in which ischemic endothelium leads to increased capillary permeability and tissue swelling may be severe enough to induce compartment syndrome. This patient's ischemic injury likely resulted from the femoral artery clot in addition to cross-clamping during surgery. Reperfusion then caused oxidative stress and inflammation, worsening tissue damage and swelling (i.e., ischemia-reperfusion edema). Increased compartment pressure obstructs venous outflow and can collapse arterioles, further worsening tissue perfusion and ischemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Rhabdomyolysis may result from ischemic injury to the extremity (potentially leading to compartment syndrome in severe cases). It first manifests with muscle tenderness, as seen here. But rhabdomyolysis is also commonly associated with myoglobinuria and acute kidney injury, which are not seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Cholesterol embolism may complicate arterial interventions such as embolectomy. From a distal source such as the femoral artery, a cholesterol embolism may manifest with sudden-onset severe pain at the foot and leg and diminished pedal pulse. This patient has risk factors for cholesterol deposits (hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, diabetes mellitus), but whole-extremity involvement, as well as swelling and stiffness of the leg, make embolism less likely. Moreover, a cholesterol embolism typically causes skin changes (livedo reticularis, purpura, necrosis) over the affected area.

E) INCORRECT:

Cellulitis may also manifest with unilateral leg pain and swelling, but more commonly also warmth, erythema, and localized tenderness. This patient has a diffusely tender leg and does not have any signs suggesting infection such as fever or tachycardia.
questions.hint: This patient's swollen, painful leg with reduced pedal pulses and paresthesia are suggestive of compartment syndrome.

questions.text:
Eighteen hours after undergoing surgery for a splenic rupture and liver laceration following a high-speed motor vehicle collision, a 23-year-old man's pulse is 140/min, blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg, and central venous pressure is 19 cm H2O. He was transfused with 6 units of packed red blood cells during surgery. Examination shows jugular venous distention. There is a midline surgical incision with no erythema or discharge. The abdomen is tense and distended. The total urine output over the past 6 hours is 90 mL. Serum studies show:


Urea nitrogen
80 mg/dL


Creatinine
3.0 mg/dL


HCO3-

29 mEq/L


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reopen abdomen and cover with plastic

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is used to correct severe coagulopathy or coagulopathic patients with significant hemorrhage. This patient is at risk of coagulopathy (trauma, recent large-volume RBC transfusion), and he is hemodynamically unstable with abdominal tension, which could result from intraabdominal hemorrhage. However, hemorrhage causes intravascular volume depletion leading to low jugular venous pressure and flat neck veins, rather than jugular venous distention as in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Abdominal decompression by laparotomy with temporary closure is indicated to relieve intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) in abdominal compartment syndrome with signs of progressive organ failure (e.g., acute kidney injury). Medical management (e.g., paracentesis, pain control, luminal decompression by nasogastric tube) and regular IAP checks follow surgical decompression and should continue until IAP is consistently < 12 mm Hg. Prolonged surgery (especially involving the abdominal compartment) requiring ample IV fluid and transfusions may result in a rise in IAP secondary to tissue fluid build-up. Rising IAP causes a tense and distended abdomen and leads to abdominal compartment syndrome if the pressure continues to rise (especially ≥ 20 mm Hg, even less in children). This condition prevents blood in the inferior vena cava from reaching the heart (↓ preload), thereby causing a reduction in cardiac output that leads to hypotension, reactive tachycardia, and prerenal kidney injury due to reduced perfusion (causes oliguria and BUN:Cr > 20). In some cases, elevated IAP extends into the thoracic compartment, which causes jugular venous distention.

When abdominal compartment syndrome is suspected, IAP should be measured. Patients with IAP > 20 mm Hg require emergency surgery; patients with IAP < 20 mm Hg are generally trialed on medical therapy. This patient's critical clinical condition would likely require surgical decompression regardless of his IAP.

C) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular epinephrine is the most important emergency medical treatment for anaphylaxis, which can result from administration of any drug or blood product and can manifest with hypotension and tachycardia (i.e., anaphylactic shock). Anaphylaxis typically arises very shortly after administration of the offending drug (minutes-to-hours) and is associated with urticaria and/or angioedema. Anaphylactic shock causes systemic vasodilation leading to low jugular venous pressure and flat neck veins, whereas this patient has jugular venous distention. Furthermore, anaphylaxis would not explain this patient's tense abdomen.

D) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics are indicated for bacterial infection (e.g., sepsis), for which this patient is high risk. Infection typically requires days to progress to sepsis, rather than hours. Also, hypotension in sepsis is due to bacterial toxin-induced vasodilation, which would cause low jugular venous pressure, rather than this patient's jugular venous distention.

E) INCORRECT:

Angiographic embolization is indicated for patients with splenic hemorrhage who are hemodynamically stable. This patient is at high risk of splenic hemorrhage (recent splenic rupture and surgery), but hemorrhage causes intravascular volume depletion, leading to low jugular venous pressure and flat neck veins rather than the jugular venous distention in this patient. Also, this patient is hemodynamically unstable, so angiographic embolization would not be indicated in any case. Laparotomy is the treatment of choice for hemodynamically unstable patients with evidence of splenic hemorrhage.

F) INCORRECT:

Hemicolectomy is indicated for intestinal diseases that are not medically treatable. Severe abdominal pain and rigidity are common symptoms of severe intestinal diseases, but the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms is not intestinal disease.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is often secondary to massive volume resuscitation (e.g., postoperative patients, treatment of hypovolemic shock, severe burns).

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after being bitten by a rattlesnake. He was hiking in the Arizona desert when he accidentally stepped on the snake and it bit his right leg. His pulse is 135/min and blood pressure is 104/81 mm Hg. Examination shows right lower leg swelling, ecchymosis, and blistering. Right ankle dorsiflexion elicits severe pain. A manometer inserted in the lateral compartment of the lower leg shows an intracompartmental pressure of 67 mm Hg. In addition to administration of the antivenom, the patient undergoes fasciotomy. Two weeks later, he reports difficulty with walking. Neurologic examination shows a loss of sensation over the lower part of the lateral side of the right leg and the dorsum of the right foot. Right foot eversion is 1/5. There is no weakness upon dorsiflexion. Which of the following nerves is most likely injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A tibial nerve injury causes impaired motor function of the flexor muscles of the foot, leading to an inability to invert the foot or walk on the toes or balls of the foot, none of which is seen here. Patients will also experience sensory loss on the sole of the foot, not the dorsum of the foot. Moreover, injury during a lateral fasciotomy is unlikely because the tibial nerve is located in the deep posterior compartment of the leg.

B) INCORRECT:

The sural nerve is a purely sensory branch of the tibial nerve, which runs superficially to the superficial posterior compartment of the leg. Injury to this nerve causes impaired sensation on the posterolateral side of the lower leg, ankle, heel, and foot, but not on the anterolateral side of the leg and dorsum of the foot. Moreover, patients will not present with motor findings. Finally, injury to this nerve during lateral fasciotomy is unlikely given its location on the posterior aspect of the leg.

C) INCORRECT:

A deep peroneal nerve injury causes impaired motor function of the foot and toe extensors as well as decreased sensation in the webspace between the hallux and second digit of the foot. Patients will present with difficulties with dorsiflexion and eversion that lead to the characteristic steppage gait. This patient does not have any weakness in dorsiflexion. Moreover, injury during a lateral fasciotomy is unlikely because the deep peroneal nerve is located in the anterior compartment of the leg.

D) CORRECT:

The superficial peroneal nerve supplies motor innervation to the lateral compartment of the leg, the main functions of which are foot eversion and plantar flexion. Injury to this nerve compromises foot eversion but does not affect dorsiflexion, which is produced by the anterior compartment of the leg that is innervated by the deep peroneal nerve. The superficial peroneal nerve also supplies sensory innervation to the distal part of the anterolateral aspect of the leg and the dorsum of the foot (except for the first web space); injury to this nerve thus results in loss of sensation in this area.

This patient originally presented with features of compartment syndrome (severe leg swelling and pain, increased compartment pressure) and underwent emergency fasciotomy, which is associated with a risk of nerve injury. Risk factors for compartment syndrome include animal venoms (e.g., rattlesnake bites), circumferential burns, long bone fractures, and crush injuries.
Image Description:

Transverse section of the right leg (caudal view)

The interosseous membrane and deep fascial septa divide the leg into three compartments:
1. Anterior (extensor) compartment: bound by the tibia and the anterior intermuscular septum (junction of blue and purple compartments)
2. Lateral (fibular) compartment: bound by the anterior and posterior intermuscular septum (junction of purple and green compartments)
3. Posterior (flexor) compartment, which is further divided into:
- Deep posterior compartment: bound by the interosseous membrane anteriorly (junction of blue and orange compartments) and the transverse intermuscular septum posteriorly (junction of orange and green)
- Superficial posterior compartment: posterior to the transverse intermuscular septum

E) INCORRECT:

The saphenous nerve is a purely sensory nerve that innervates the medial side of the leg, knee, and foot. Fasciotomy of the lateral compartment of the leg would not affect the saphenous nerve because it travels medially down the leg to the foot. Additionally, injury to the saphenous nerve would not present with motor findings.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms are most likely due to intraoperative injury of the nerve that innervates the fibularis longus and fibularis brevis muscles.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is admitted to the hospital after sustaining a left supracondylar humerus fracture and left proximal forearm fracture in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He undergoes closed reduction and percutaneous pinning. The day after his surgery, he is crying and has severe left arm pain. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 116/76 mm Hg. When his fingers are extended passively, he yells in agony and says the pain is even worse. After the cast is removed, physical examination shows a diffuse firm swelling of the forearm and severe pain with palpation. The left radial pulse is palpable and the capillary refill time is 2 seconds. Which of the following is the most appropriate study to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Needle manometry confirms the diagnosis of acute compartment syndrome (ACS) by measuring compartment pressure. As compartment pressure approaches diastolic pressure, blood supply is increasingly compromised. A delta pressure (diastolic pressure - compartment pressure) of ≤ 30 mm Hg is diagnostic of ACS. If needle manometry is not readily available and ACS is highly suspected, a confirmatory test is unnecessary and the patient must undergo emergency forearm fasciotomy. Fasciotomy must be performed within 4–6 hours of symptom onset to prevent muscle and soft tissue necrosis and irreversible nerve damage. Ischemic features (e.g., pallor, pulselessness, poikilothermia, paralysis, increased capillary refill time) are usually late findings of ACS (typically occurring 4–6 hours after symptom onset) and are associated with a poor prognosis.

B) INCORRECT:

CT arteriography can show filling defects and is the most appropriate test to confirm thrombotic or embolic arterial occlusion, which are the most common causes of acute limb ischemia. This patient has acute compartment syndrome (ACS), and his palpable pulses and normal capillary refill time indicate that he has not yet developed acute limb ischemia. In ACS, arteriography will show a filling defect only if muscle compartment pressure exceeds arterial blood pressure and collapses arteries, which occurs late in the course of the condition. Therefore, arteriography is not appropriate for diagnosing ACS.

C) INCORRECT:

Duplex ultrasonography (combined B-mode and pulse wave Doppler) is often used in the initial workup of acute limb ischemia. This patient has acute compartment syndrome (ACS), and his palpable pulses and normal capillary refill time indicate that he has not yet developed acute limb ischemia. In ACS, certain Doppler findings (e.g., loss of early diastolic blood flow reversal distal to the site of ACS, increased peak systolic arterial blood velocity proximal to the site of ACS) might be seen in the early course of the condition. However, these findings are neither sensitive nor specific enough to confirm the diagnosis of ACS.

D) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the affected extremity would show soft tissue edema, which is expected in a patient with acute compartment syndrome (ACS). However, MRI does not differentiate between the expected edema in patients following traumatic fractures and surgery, which this patient has experienced, and compartment edema, seen in ACS. This diagnostic study is, therefore, of little utility in a patient with early signs of ACS.

E) INCORRECT:

Nerve conduction studies are usually used in the follow-up of patients with a history of acute compartment syndrome (ACS) to assess for nerve damage, a common complication of ACS. In the acute setting, however, a different diagnostic study is used to confirm ACS.

F) INCORRECT:

Serum creatine kinase (CK) concentration can be elevated in acute compartment syndrome (ACS) because of rhabdomyolysis resulting from muscle ischemia. Serum CK concentration may be used as an adjunct in ACS to assess for rhabdomyolysis and to guide fluid resuscitation, which helps to prevent the development or worsening of acute kidney injury due to rhabdomyolysis. However, serum CK concentration is neither sensitive nor specific for ACS, as CK levels can be elevated in other situations (e.g., strenuous exercise, skeletal muscle injury due to trauma, surgery, myocardial infarction). Therefore, serum CK concentration is of little utility in confirming the diagnosis of ACS.
questions.hint: Severely tender forearm swelling accompanied by excruciating pain that worsens with palpation and passive muscle stretch in a patient with a history of bone fractures is suggestive of acute compartment syndrome. Palpable pulses and a normal capillary refill time indicate an early, reversible presentation.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman is hospitalized after sustaining blunt trauma to her left lower extremity in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. Two hours after admission, the pain in her leg has increased significantly.
She has no significant medical history, and her only medication is an oral contraceptive started 3 months ago.
On examination, her left lower leg is bruised, tense, moderately erythematous, and warm. Passive dorsiflexion and plantar flexion of the left ankle elicit pain in the anterior lower leg and in the calf musculature, respectively. Sensation in the leg is normal.
Radiographs of her left tibia and fibula show no fracture.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Serial measurements of the circumference of the left leg
Obtain an MRI of the left lower leg
Obtain a Doppler ultrasound of the left leg

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serial physical examinations, including measurement of leg circumference, are not sensitive for the diagnosis of ACS.

B) INCORRECT:

MRI is not effective in the diagnosis of early ACS.

C) CORRECT:

The findings of pain out of proportion to the injury, pain with passive muscle stretching, swelling, and compartment tightness in a patient who sustained trauma to the lower extremity suggest acute compartment syndrome (ACS) of the lower leg. Patients with ACS commonly have normal pulses in the distal extremity. Paresthesia with motor dysfunction is usually a late finding.

If untreated, the swelling and increased pressure from the traumatically damaged tissue will cause muscle death and possible permanent leg dysfunction.

In a patient with suspected ACS, compartment pressure measurements should be performed early by an orthopedist or trained surgeon and should be repeated often to monitor for deterioration. The lower leg has four compartments: anterior, deep posterior, lateral, and superficial posterior. The anterior and deep posterior compartments are the most common sites for ACS. Compartment pressures are measured by injecting a saline solution into an anesthetized compartment of interest and measuring the resistance to that injection via manometer. If the pressure is abnormally high, then the definitive treatment for ACS is fasciotomy.

Key learning point: The most important step in the management of acute compartment syndrome is surgical evaluation and decompression (fasciotomy).

D) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound is not effective in the diagnosis of early ACS.

E) INCORRECT:

Although elevation and analgesia are often used to alleviate the pain and swelling associated with orthopedic injuries (e.g., sprains, strains, fractures), neither will provide the definitive management required for acute compartment syndrome.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man reports pain in his left lower extremity that began this morning, right after he finished playing in a football game in which his left leg was struck by the helmet of another player. The pain has been worsening throughout the day despite treatment with ibuprofen, acetaminophen, and, upon arrival to the emergency department, intravenous hydromorphone.
The anterior portion of the patient's left lower extremity is swollen, firm and tender to palpation. The pain is exacerbated by active and passive motion of the ankle. He has normal distal pulses and brisk capillary refill. His sensation is intact to light touch, and he has a normal neurologic examination.
Radiographs of his left tibia and fibula are obtained (figures 1 and 2).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?

choices.text: Avulsion fracture of the lateral malleolus
Contusion of the left lower extremity

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A malleolar fracture would cause pain on direct palpation of the medial or lateral malleolus. Worsening pain would be unlikely with this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

The pain of a contusion would not worsen over time.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s radiographs of the left tibia and fibula are normal except for chronic changes related to childhood Osgood-Schlatter disease, unrelated to this presentation.

Acute compartment syndrome is an urgent condition characterized by increased swelling and pressure that ultimately cause tissue damage and neurovascular compromise. A sensitive and early sign of the syndrome is pain out of proportion to what the physical examination suggests. Other hallmarks of the diagnosis (the classic "P"s) are pain with passive range of motion, paresthesias, pallor, paralysis, and pulselessness. However, not all patients present with all of these findings, and the presence of palpable pulses does not rule out the possibility of compartment syndrome.

Acute compartment syndrome most commonly occurs in the distal lower extremity, but it can also occur in the forearms or anywhere else in the body where there is a confined space. It typically occurs in association with an acute fracture, crush injury, severe muscle injury (as in this case), or prolonged immobilization. Compartment pressures should be obtained when acute compartment syndrome is suspected.

Fasciotomy is the treatment for confirmed cases of acute compartment syndrome. Some experts advocate performing a fasciotomy if the compartment pressures exceed 30 mm Hg. However, others recommend fasciotomy only if the difference between the diastolic blood pressure and the tissue pressure is <30 mm Hg.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis for a patient who has firm swelling and increasing pain with passive range of motion in the anterior compartment of the distal lower extremity is acute compartment syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Shin splints do not typically cause swelling and pain on passive range of motion.

E) INCORRECT:

A stress fracture is unlikely in this patient, given the presentation of pain shortly after trauma to the leg; in addition, stress fractures do not typically cause swelling of the extremity.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman who has a right tibial diaphyseal fracture describes progression of severe pain and a pins-and-needles sensation in her right leg.
Her vital signs are stable, and she has a blood pressure of 140/65 mm Hg. There is pain with passive plantar flexion and dorsiflexion of the foot. Her distal pulses are intact. Neurologic examination of the lower extremity is normal.
Immediate surgical consultation is requested, and pain control is initiated.
What is the most appropriate next step to take while awaiting a surgical opinion?

choices.text: Elevate the leg to a 30-degree angle
Place the leg in a dependent position
Immobilize the leg with the ankle in slight plantar flexion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Research is ongoing to examine the role of nitric oxide in preventing the development of an impending acute compartment syndrome, but this is not a current accepted practice.

B) INCORRECT:

The use of mannitol to reduce tissue edema is being studied, but it is not an accepted practice for routine care.

C) INCORRECT:

Elevating the leg may reduce arterial flow and narrow the arterial-venous gradient, and lowering the leg into a dependent position may increase swelling and compartment pressure. Any immobilization should be done with care not to create any restriction. The patient should be examined on a frequent basis.

D) INCORRECT:

Elevating the leg may reduce arterial flow and narrow the arterial-venous gradient, and lowering the leg into a dependent position may increase swelling and compartment pressure. Any immobilization should be done with care not to create any restriction. The patient should be examined on a frequent basis.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s signs and symptoms are worrisome for acute compartment syndrome, which is found in 2% to 9% of tibia fractures, most commonly from tibial diaphyseal fractures. Muscle groups in the limbs are divided into compartments, separated by strong fascial membranes. In compartment syndrome, a pressure increase within the compartment (as the fascia prevents expansion of tissue volume from swelling or bleeding) leads to compromised circulation and tissue function — and ultimately cellular anoxia.

Signs and symptoms of acute compartment syndrome usually progress during a period of hours and include a tense, “wood-like” feeling along with the classic “P”s: pain (at rest or with passive muscle stretching) that is out of proportion to examination or injury, paresthesia, paralysis (a late finding), pulselessness (a late finding), and pallor.

Immediate surgical consultation is warranted if acute compartment syndrome is suspected, and the patient should be transported to a facility where compartment pressures and a fasciotomy can be performed if needed.

In patients such as this, where acute compartment syndrome is likely, any compressive bandages should be removed, the limb should be placed at the level of the heart, and an emergency surgical consultation should be obtained. While awaiting a surgical opinion, the patient should be asked to keep the leg immobilized with the ankle in slight plantar flexion; this position may increase the space in the deep posterior compartment without increasing anterior compartment pressure.

Infusion of crystalloid, or other methods of maintaining adequate hydration, is important for treatment of rhabdomyolysis, which may be a complication of acute compartment syndrome.

Key learning point: A patient with suspected acute compartment syndrome from a tibial diaphyseal fracture requires immediate surgical consultation and pain relief. While awaiting a surgical opinion, the patient should be asked to immobilize the leg with the ankle in a position of slight plantar flexion.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl is hospitalized after sustaining blunt trauma to her left lower extremity in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. Two hours after admission, the pain in her leg has increased significantly.
She has no significant medical history, and her only medication is an oral contraceptive started 3 months ago.
On examination, her left lower leg is bruised, tense, moderately erythematous, and warm. Passive dorsiflexion and plantar flexion of the left ankle elicit pain in the anterior lower leg and in the calf musculature, respectively. Sensation in the leg is normal.
Radiographs of her left tibia and fibula show no fracture.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Obtain a Doppler ultrasound of the left leg
Serial measurements of the circumference of the left leg
Obtain an MRI of the left lower leg

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound is not effective in the diagnosis of early ACS.

B) INCORRECT:

Serial physical examinations, including measurement of leg circumference, are not sensitive for the diagnosis of ACS.

C) INCORRECT:

MRI is not effective in the diagnosis of early ACS.

D) INCORRECT:

Although elevation and analgesia are often used to alleviate the pain and swelling associated with orthopedic injuries (e.g., sprains, strains, fractures), neither will provide the definitive management required for acute compartment syndrome.

E) CORRECT:

The findings of pain out of proportion to the injury, pain with passive muscle stretching, swelling, and compartment tightness in a patient who sustained trauma to the lower extremity suggest acute compartment syndrome (ACS) of the lower leg. Patients with ACS commonly have normal pulses in the distal extremity. Paresthesia with motor dysfunction is usually a late finding.

If untreated, the swelling and increased pressure from the traumatically damaged tissue will cause muscle death and possible permanent leg dysfunction.

In a patient with suspected ACS, compartment pressure measurements should be performed early by an orthopedist or trained surgeon and should be repeated often to monitor for deterioration. The lower leg has four compartments: anterior, deep posterior, lateral, and superficial posterior. The anterior and deep posterior compartments are the most common sites for ACS. Compartment pressures are measured by injecting a saline solution into an anesthetized compartment of interest and measuring the resistance to that injection via manometer. If the pressure is abnormally high, then the definitive treatment for ACS is fasciotomy.

Key learning point: The most important step in the management of acute compartment syndrome is surgical evaluation and decompression (fasciotomy).

questions.text:
An 18-year-old young man reports pain in his left lower extremity that began this morning, right after he finished playing in a football game in which his left leg was struck by the helmet of another player. The pain has been worsening throughout the day despite treatment with ibuprofen, acetaminophen, and, upon arrival to the emergency department, intravenous hydromorphone.
The anterior portion of the patient's left lower extremity is swollen and tender to palpation. The pain is exacerbated by active and passive motion of the ankle. He has normal distal pulses and brisk capillary refill. His sensation is intact to light touch, and he has a normal neurologic examination. He has no point tenderness noted over his lower extremity.
Radiographs of his left tibia and fibula are obtained (figures 1 and 2).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?

choices.text: Contusion of the left lower extremity
Avulsion fracture of the lateral malleolus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The pain of a contusion would not worsen over time.

B) INCORRECT:

A stress fracture is unlikely in this patient, given the presentation of pain shortly after trauma to the leg; in addition, stress fractures do not typically cause swelling of the extremity.

C) INCORRECT:

A malleolar fracture would cause pain on direct palpation of the medial or lateral malleolus. Worsening pain would be unlikely with this condition.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s radiographs of the left tibia and fibula are normal except for chronic changes related to childhood Osgood-Schlatter disease, unrelated to this presentation.

Acute compartment syndrome is an urgent condition characterized by increased swelling and pressure that ultimately cause tissue damage and neurovascular compromise. A sensitive and early sign of the syndrome is pain out of proportion to what the physical examination suggests. Other hallmarks of the diagnosis (the classic "P"s) are pain with passive range of motion, paresthesias, pallor, paralysis, and pulselessness. However, not all patients present with all of these findings, and the presence of palpable pulses does not rule out the possibility of compartment syndrome.

Acute compartment syndrome most commonly occurs in the distal lower extremity, but it can also occur in the forearms or anywhere else in the body where there is a confined space. It typically occurs in association with an acute fracture, crush injury, severe muscle injury (as in this case), or prolonged immobilization. Compartment pressures should be obtained when acute compartment syndrome is suspected.

Fasciotomy is the treatment for confirmed cases of acute compartment syndrome. Some experts advocate performing a fasciotomy if the compartment pressures exceed 30 mm Hg. However, others recommend fasciotomy only if the difference between the diastolic blood pressure and the tissue pressure is <30 mm Hg.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis for a patient who has swelling and increasing pain with passive range of motion in the anterior compartment of the distal lower extremity is acute compartment syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

A bowing fracture of the fibula may be seen in younger children but is uncommon among adolescents. In addition, it would be visualized on radiographs, and worsening pain would be unlikely.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man comes to the emergency department 4 hours after a bike accident for severe pain and swelling in his right leg. He is in moderate distress. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. There is swelling surrounding a 2 cm laceration 13 cm below the right knee. The lower two-thirds of the tibia is tender to palpation and the skin is pale and cool to the touch. The anterior tibial, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis pulses are weak. Capillary refill time of the right big toe is 4 seconds. Passive dorsiflexion of his right foot causes severe pain in his calf. An x-ray of the right leg shows a dislocated fracture of the tibial center with posterior displacement of the distal tibial part. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

One of the many indications of LMWH is the treatment of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). DVT can manifest with swelling of the lower limb and pain in the calf muscle on dorsiflexion of the foot. However, in patients with DVT, the extremities are usually warm and have a reddish-purple hue, normal pulses, and/or distended superficial veins.

B) INCORRECT:

Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) with an intramedullary nail are usually the treatment of choice for many types of open fractures of the tibial shaft, which this patient has. However, the presence of compartment syndrome warrants a more urgent procedure to save the limb before any definitive therapy is implemented.

C) INCORRECT:

An above knee cast may be used to nonsurgically treat a noncomminuted, minimally displaced tibial shaft fracture. However, this patient's fracture is open and has significant displacement, which requires surgical treatment. Regardless, a cast is contraindicated in this patient with compartment syndrome as it would drastically increase compartment pressure and further increase the risk of developing limb ischemia.

D) CORRECT:

Fasciotomy is the treatment of choice for compartment syndrome. It should be conducted within six hours of the onset of clinical symptoms (to prevent necrosis, irreversible nerve damage, and possible amputation) and followed up with open wound management. The diagnosis is primarily clinical; however, needle manometry to calculate the delta pressure (diastolic blood pressure - intracompartmental pressure) is often performed to confirm the diagnosis. A delta pressure < 30 mm Hg confirms acute compartment syndrome, which is an indication for fasciotomy. For patients who present extremely late (3–5 days after onset), amputation is the treatment of last resort.

E) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin is used to treat skin and soft tissue infections caused by anaerobic bacteria and certain gram-positive organisms such as MRSA. However, the history of trauma in this patient along with pale, cool skin instead of warm, erythematous skin, and the absence of fever suggest a noninfectious condition. If surgery is indicated, clindamycin is considered an alternative to cefazolin for surgical prophylaxis in patients with a beta-lactam allergy. However, the presence of compartment syndrome in this patient warrants a more urgent procedure to save the limb before any definitive therapy can be implemented.
questions.hint: Findings of a tibial fracture, pale, cool skin, weak peripheral pulses, increased capillary refill time, and pain in the calf muscle on passively dorsiflexing the foot are consistent with acute compartment syndrome and impending limb ischemia.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man is treated with a cast for a radial shaft fracture. Two days later, he presents with severe forearm pain, especially on passive extension of his fingers. He reports tingling in his fingertips and that the pain is not alleviated by increasing doses of analgesics. His forearm compartments feel tense, but pulses remain palpable.
Which mechanism best explains the earliest symptom in this clinical scenario?

choices.text: Localized inflammation of the fracture site periosteum
Reflex vasospasm triggered by local trauma
Toxic muscle breakdown products irritating peripheral nerves
Nerve ischemia caused by elevated compartment pressure

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Periosteal inflammation causes localized pain at the fracture site, noticeable on palpation or active use. It does not explain the severe pain on passive extension or tingling, which result from elevated compartment pressure affecting nerves and muscles.

B) INCORRECT:

Reflex vasospasm from trauma might cause localized vasoconstriction, affecting larger vessels and potentially diminishing pulses. However, the preserved pulses and severe pain on passive extension suggest increased compartment pressure, not vasospasm, as the cause of ischemic pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Muscle breakdown products can irritate nerves in extensive necrosis or rhabdomyolysis. However, the early severe pain on passive extension is due to acute compartment pressure causing ischemia, not toxic products, which are a later event.

D) CORRECT:

Increased intracompartmental pressure in a closed space, such as the forearm after a fracture, reduces capillary perfusion, leading to nerve ischemia. This ischemia manifests as severe pain, especially on passive extension, and sensory symptoms like tingling. The microcirculation is particularly vulnerable, causing neural irritation and pain before muscle damage or necrosis occurs. Larger vessels may remain patent, but the compromised microvascular flow affects nerve function, explaining the early symptoms.

Key learning point: In compartment syndrome, the earliest symptom of severe pain is primarily due to nerve hypoxia caused by increased pressure within the compartment.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department after a fall from a height, landing on his outstretched right arm. He complains of severe right forearm pain that has worsened over the past hour. Examination shows a painful, swollen forearm with tense compartments. Pain intensifies with passive finger extension. Distal pulses remain palpable, though capillary refill is delayed. He is visibly distressed by severe, escalating pain. Vital signs are stable.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Elevate the arm above heart level

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acute compartment syndrome manifests with severe pain, pain on passive muscle stretching, and a tense, swollen compartment. Measuring intracompartmental pressure confirms the diagnosis, with pressures above 30 mm Hg or a delta pressure (diastolic blood pressure minus compartment pressure) below 30 mm Hg indicating severity. This measurement guides the urgency of surgical intervention to prevent permanent damage.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected acute compartment syndrome, measuring compartment pressure is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis and prevent permanent damage.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous analgesics relieve pain but do not confirm compartment syndrome, which requires intracompartmental pressure measurement. Analgesics may mask symptoms, complicating evaluation, while the focus is on obtaining objective diagnostic data.

C) INCORRECT:

Elevating the limb can reduce edema in less critical injuries but may worsen ischemia in acute compartment syndrome by decreasing arterial inflow. Diagnosis relies on intracompartmental pressure measurement, not limb elevation, which can exacerbate tissue hypoperfusion.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI evaluates soft tissue injuries but is impractical for acute compartment syndrome, where severe pain, tense compartments, and pain with passive extension suggest the diagnosis. MRI delays can lead to irreversible damage, as the condition requires urgent confirmation through intracompartmental pressure measurement.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department after a motor vehicle collision. He complains of severe right lower leg pain that worsens with minimal movement. He denies any prior medical conditions. The leg appears tense and swollen with tight compartments. Pain is disproportionate to the exam, and he experiences intense pain upon passive dorsiflexion of the ankle. Sensation is decreased over the dorsum of the foot, and foot pulses are palpable. Compartments feel rigid, and capillary refill is normal. He has received intravenous opioids with minimal relief (see report).
Radiographs: Displaced mid-shaft tibial fracture
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Elevate the limb above heart level and continue opioid analgesia
Long-leg cast and reassess in 24 hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While elevation and analgesia are common in musculoskeletal injuries, they are inappropriate for acute compartment syndrome. Elevating the limb can decrease arterial inflow, worsening ischemia, and opioids do not address the underlying compartmental hypertension.

B) CORRECT:

Acute compartment syndrome is a surgical emergency characterized by increased pressure within a closed muscle compartment, leading to decreased perfusion and potential ischemic injury. This patient exhibits hallmark signs, including severe pain out of proportion to the injury, pain on passive stretch, tense compartments, and neurologic deficits. Despite palpable pulses and normal capillary refill, ischemia can still occur. Emergent fasciotomy is the definitive treatment to relieve pressure, restore perfusion, and prevent irreversible damage to muscles and nerves, especially in the context of a tibial fracture.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected compartment syndrome, fasciotomy is the definitive treatment to relieve pressure and prevent irreversible damage.

C) INCORRECT:

A long-leg cast is used for stable fractures without signs of compartment syndrome. In this patient, the severe pain, tense compartments, and neurologic deficits indicate acute compartment syndrome. Casting can exacerbate compartment pressures and delay necessary intervention, risking irreversible damage.

D) INCORRECT:

Intracompartmental pressure measurements are useful when the diagnosis is uncertain. However, this patient presents with clear clinical signs of compartment syndrome, making immediate surgical intervention more appropriate than delaying for pressure measurements.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department after a motorcycle crash. He complains of severe pain in his left lower leg despite intravenous analgesics. The leg appears swollen and tense, with marked pain on passive extension of his toes. He reports numbness in the foot. Pedal pulses are difficult to palpate.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Elevate the leg and apply ice packs
Increase intravenous analgesics and repeat neurovascular checks in 2 hours

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acute compartment syndrome results from increased pressure within a closed fascial compartment, compromising tissue perfusion and risking irreversible damage to muscles and nerves. Marked pain on passive stretching, such as toe extension, is a sensitive indicator of compartment syndrome. Numbness and difficult-to-palpate pulses suggest significant neural and vascular compromise. Prompt surgical fasciotomy is essential to release elevated pressures, restore blood flow, and prevent lasting dysfunction. In cases with clear clinical findings, immediate intervention is prioritized over diagnostic measurements to avert time-sensitive ischemic injury.

Key learning point: Acute compartment syndrome is a surgical emergency characterized by severe pain, numbness, and absent pulses, and requires immediate fasciotomy to relieve pressure and prevent irreversible damage.
Image Description:

Intraoperative photograph of the left thigh of a patient with compartment syndrome of the left lower extremity secondary to a femoral shaft fracture

A longitudinal incision through the skin, subcutaneous tissue, and deep fascia has been created on the anterolateral aspect of the left thigh. The thigh muscles are visible through the incision and appear viable (red).

This is an example of a typical fasciotomy incision, an emergency intervention to relieve compartmental pressure.

B) INCORRECT:

Compartment pressure measurements are useful when the diagnosis is unclear. However, the patient's severe pain, pain on passive toe extension, swelling, tense compartment, and neurologic symptoms are characteristic of compartment syndrome. Immediate surgical decompression is necessary, as delays for diagnostic evaluations could lead to irreversible damage.

C) INCORRECT:

Limb elevation and ice packs are contraindicated in acute compartment syndrome. Elevation can lower arterial perfusion pressure, worsening ischemia, while ice packs induce vasoconstriction, reducing blood flow. The patient's severe pain, swelling, numbness, and diminished pulses indicate increased intracompartmental pressure, necessitating surgical decompression rather than conservative measures.

D) INCORRECT:

The patient's severe pain, unrelieved by analgesics, and sensory deficits indicate critical intracompartmental pressure. Increasing analgesics and delaying intervention risk masking worsening symptoms and allowing irreversible damage. Immediate surgical intervention is required to address the underlying ischemic process.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man, who is a construction worker, presents 2 hours after being struck by a falling beam and sustaining a closed midshaft tibia fracture. He reports severe leg pain that has worsened since arrival despite IV morphine. On examination, his lower leg is moderately swollen; palpation is painful and shows muscle firmness. Passive dorsiflexion of the foot elicits significant pain. Distal pulses are present and capillary refill is 2 seconds. Sensation to light touch appears intact, but the patient reports some numbness in the web space between his first and second toes. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Obtain urgent orthopedic consultation for operative fracture fixation
Administer additional IV opioids and reassess in 30 minutes
Order CT angiography to evaluate vascular injury
Elevate the extremity above heart level

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While orthopedic consultation will be necessary, operative fracture fixation is not the priority in this patient with possible compartment syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Additional opioids might mask important clinical signs and delay diagnosis of suspected compartment syndrome. Pain out of proportion to injury that worsens despite adequate analgesia is a hallmark of compartment syndrome and requires immediate diagnostic evaluation.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has concerning early signs of compartment syndrome: pain worsening despite adequate analgesia, pain with passive stretching, muscle firmness, and early neurological changes (sensory deficits in deep peroneal nerve distribution). With early clinical findings of compartment syndrome, measuring intracompartmental pressures is essential to confirm the diagnosis before proceeding to emergency fasciotomy.

D) INCORRECT:

CT angiography is not indicated for diagnosing compartment syndrome and would delay appropriate management.

E) INCORRECT:

Elevation above heart level is contraindicated in suspected compartment syndrome because it may worsen ischemia by reducing blood flow to the affected compartment. The affected limb should be positioned at heart level to optimize perfusion.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man, who is a construction worker, presents 4 hours after a crush injury to his forearm from falling scaffolding. He reports severe, progressively worsening pain that is not relieved by morphine. Physical examination shows a tense, swollen forearm with severe pain on passive finger extension. Radial and ulnar pulses are present. Intracompartmental pressure is 25 mm Hg. Blood pressure is 140/70 mm Hg. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Elevation of the extremity above heart level
Repeat compartment pressure measurement in 2 hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Discharge is inappropriate for this patient, given the clinical presentation consistent with acute compartment syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

CT angiography is not indicated for diagnosing compartment syndrome and would delay appropriate management.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Immediate fasciotomy is indicated for acute compartment syndrome. Pain unresponsive to opioids and pain with passive stretch are highly concerning for this condition. The diagnosis is confirmed by calculating the delta pressure (diastolic blood pressure - intracompartmental pressure), which has a threshold of 30 mm Hg; this patient's delta pressure is 45 mm Hg.

D) INCORRECT:

Elevation above heart level is contraindicated in suspected compartment syndrome as it may worsen ischemia by reducing blood flow to the affected compartment. The limb should be positioned at heart level to optimize perfusion.

E) INCORRECT:

Serial measurements would delay necessary surgical intervention. This patient's delta pressure of 45 mm Hg combined with classic clinical findings warrants immediate fasciotomy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a motorcycle accident. He sustained a closed, displaced fracture of the right tibia, which was reduced and placed in a long leg splint. Four hours later, he complains of severe, escalating pain in his right lower leg that is unrelieved by two doses of intravenous morphine. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. The right lower leg is markedly swollen and feels extremely tense on palpation. He has excruciating pain with passive plantar flexion of his great toe and reports numbness between the first and second toes. Distal pulses are palpable. Which of the following is the most definitive and urgently indicated intervention?

choices.text: Urgent application of an external fixator
Immediate open reduction and internal fixation
Bivalving the splint and elevating the limb

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An external fixator is a method used to stabilize a fracture, particularly in the setting of significant soft tissue injury. While it may be used to manage the tibial fracture, it does not treat the acute compartment syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) is the definitive treatment for the tibial fracture itself. However, it does not address the immediate, limb-threatening complication of acute compartment syndrome. Performing ORIF first would worsen ischemic injury and delay limb-saving treatment.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with acute compartment syndrome, a limb-threatening emergency that requires immediate surgical decompression. The condition is characterized by increased pressure within a fixed fascial compartment, leading to impaired tissue perfusion and potential muscle and nerve necrosis. Tibial fractures are a common cause. The cardinal findings present here are pain out of proportion to the injury, pain with passive muscle stretch, a tense compartment on palpation, and paresthesias (numbness between the first and second toes from deep peroneal nerve compression). Palpable distal pulses do not rule out this diagnosis. The definitive treatment is an emergent fasciotomy, which involves incising the fascia of all four lower leg compartments (anterior, lateral, deep posterior, superficial posterior) to relieve pressure and restore circulation.

D) INCORRECT:

Removing or bivalving any constrictive dressings, such as a splint, is an important initial step. However, this patient's tense compartment indicates intrinsic swelling, making this measure insufficient. Furthermore, limb elevation is contraindicated in established compartment syndrome as it can decrease the arterial pressure gradient and worsen tissue ischemia. The limb should be kept at the level of the heart.

E) INCORRECT:

Angiography is used to evaluate for major arterial injury. While plausible in the context of high-energy trauma, this patient has palpable distal pulses, making a major vascular occlusion less likely. Acute compartment syndrome is primarily a clinical diagnosis based on the physical examination, and delaying treatment for imaging would result in irreversible tissue damage.
questions.hint: This patient's pain out of proportion to the injury, pain with passive stretch, and a tense compartment are typical for acute compartment syndrome.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a motorcycle collision. He has a visibly deformed and swollen left lower leg. An x-ray confirms a comminuted fracture of the tibia. Despite receiving two doses of intravenous morphine, he reports excruciating, worsening pain. On examination, the leg is extremely tense and tender to palpation. He has decreased sensation over the dorsum of the foot, and passive extension of his toes elicits severe pain. Dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are palpable with a handheld Doppler. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT angiography of the lower extremity
Limb elevation and application of a bivalved cast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Measuring intracompartmental pressures is the objective method to confirm a diagnosis of acute compartment syndrome, and it is particularly useful when the clinical signs are equivocal. However, in this case, the patient presents with multiple classic and unambiguous clinical findings. Delaying definitive surgical decompression to obtain pressure measurements is unnecessary and wastes critical time, increasing the risk of irreversible ischemic injury to the muscles and nerves.

B) INCORRECT:

Although the patient is in severe pain, the pain's refractory nature to initial doses of morphine is a hallmark sign of acute compartment syndrome. Providing more analgesics would fail to address the underlying cause of ischemic pain and could mask the progression of neurologic deficits. The priority is to treat the underlying pathophysiology of dangerously elevated tissue pressure, not just the symptom of pain.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has a clear clinical diagnosis of acute compartment syndrome (ACS), a surgical emergency. The key findings are pain out of proportion to the injury (unrelieved by morphine), a tense compartment, pain with passive stretch of the muscles in the affected compartment, and paresthesia (decreased sensation on the foot dorsum from deep peroneal nerve compression). ACS occurs when swelling and bleeding increase pressure within a fixed fascial compartment, compromising perfusion and leading to irreversible muscle and nerve damage within hours. The definitive treatment is an emergency fasciotomy to decompress all four compartments of the lower leg, restore blood flow, and prevent permanent disability such as muscle necrosis, nerve palsy, and contractures.

D) INCORRECT:

CT angiography is indicated to evaluate for vascular injury, which is a concern in high-energy trauma such as a comminuted tibial fracture. However, this patient has palpable pulses via Doppler, making a major arterial transection less likely to be the primary issue. The constellation of symptoms overwhelmingly suggests acute compartment syndrome, which is the most immediate limb-threatening condition that must be addressed. Performing a CT scan would delay the time-sensitive fasciotomy.

E) INCORRECT:

While limb elevation is used to reduce swelling in many orthopedic injuries, it is contraindicated in suspected acute compartment syndrome. Elevating the limb can decrease arterial inflow and lower the perfusion pressure to the already compromised compartment, potentially worsening ischemia. Bivalving a cast is done to relieve external compression, but this patient's pressure is internal from swelling and hemorrhage within the fascial compartments.
questions.hint: Pain out of proportion to the injury, pain with passive stretch, and a tense compartment are classic signs of a limb-threatening emergency that requires immediate intervention.
